259.context: MEGA is a name/acronym and should not be translated.

260.text: MEGA is a recursive acronym and stands for "MEGA Encrypted Global Access".

262.text: MEGA is a secure cloud storage and electronic collaboration/communication service. It offers free and paid Internet-accessible storage space and bandwidth. It allows you to store and access your files from within your web browser or through dedicated client applications.

264.text: To the best of our knowledge, cloud storage and encryption are legal. Please comply with applicable laws and regulations on [B]how[/B] you use cloud storage and encryption as well as our [A]Terms of Service[/A].
264.context: Please add the [B], [/B], [A] & [/A] appropriately to your translation.

265.text: MEGA was made by the same people that had previously run one of the world's largest cloud storage businesses. Can I please have my account and my files back?

266.text: Unfortunately, MEGA has no access to any of the assets that its employees have created previously. There is no legal connection and no recycling of any code, hardware or database records, and we therefore currently see no way of recovering your legacy data.

267.text: Why base a cloud storage company in New Zealand, of all places?

268.text: Among other important reasons, New Zealand's native Māori name is "Aotearoa", which means "Land of the long white cloud".
268.context: It is good to mention the reference to Cloud in your language when translating the meaning of Aotearoa

269.text: Can I access MEGA on my mobile device?

270.text: You can access MEGA through your mobile browser, but this severely limits performance and functionality. We recommend using our dedicated mobile app for your device instead.

271.text: Can I resume interrupted up- or downloads?

272.text: Yes, as long as you do not close the browser tab, uploads and downloads will resume automatically after e.g. a network interruption or your device having entered standby/sleep mode. Please note that our servers automatically discard incomplete uploads after 48 hours of inactivity.

273.text: Can I upload the same file multiple times?

274.text: Because the server can't see filenames, filename collisions have to be dealt with on the client side. With standard settings, if you upload a file that you already seem to have in your account (same target path/filename, same size, same last modification time), it is skipped, but nothing prevents you from keeping multiple files or folders with the same name in the same folder.

275.text: How do you regulate bandwidth utilization?

276.text: Our policy is not to impose any artificial restrictions on our users unless necessitated by infrastructure bottlenecks.  We therefore reserve the right to cap user bandwidth utilization for operational reasons at any time on a per-IP basis. Your transfer queue will resume automatically once the congestion eases. No manual intervention is required.

277.text: Are there any file size limits on MEGA?

278.text: We do not impose artificial file size limits other than your available cloud drive space. While all current browsers are capable of uploading large files, downloading is size-constrained with Internet Explorer and Safari due to their incomplete HTML5 support.

279.text: Can I upload and download at the same time?

280.text: Yes. One upload and one download per browser tab can run in parallel.

281.text: Why don't you provide image thumbnails or streamed previewing of video and audio files?

282.text: Because our end-to-end encryption model inherently precludes any server-side manipulation of your data, which would be required to implement such a feature.

283.text: How do I upload files to MEGA?

284.text: There are three ways of uploading files to MEGA using your web browser:

285.text: 1. Click on the red button on the start page

286.text: 2.	Go to your file manager and click on the "File Upload" or (if you're using Chrome) "Folder 	Upload" buttons near the top

287.text: 3. Drag and drop files or (if you're using Chrome) folders onto the site

289.text: MEGA can be used with any modern web browser. However, depending on your specific browser's capabilities, some features may be unavailable - we strongly recommend using Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox or Opera Next. Advanced functionality such as automated folder synchronization or filesystem mounts will be made available through installable client applications.

291.text: You can share any subtree of your cloud drive with friends, family or coworkers. Invitation is by e-mail address. Invitees who do not have an account yet will receive an e-mail notification with a signup link. Alternatively, you can create a public link to any of your folders and export the folder-specific crypto key, making it accessible without a MEGA account. It is then your responsibility to securely transmit the folder key to the recipient(s).

292.text: To establish, modify or delete a share, simply right click on a folder in your file manager and select Sharing. There are three access levels: Read-only, read/write (files can be added, but not deleted), and full (files can be added and deleted).

293.text: If you added an e-mail address that did not have an account yet, you need to be online at least once after the recipient completes the signup process so that you can encrypt the share secret to his newly created public key.

294.text: How do I delete people from my shared folder?

295.text: Simply right click on a folder in your file manager and select sharing. You will see all people that currently have access to the shared folder. Right click on the person and choose the Delete option from the menu.

296.text: How do I recognize my shared folders?

297.text: Shared folders in your file manager have a special icon with a hand below the folder.

298.text: Can I share folders that were shared with me?

302.text: How do I link to a file on MEGA?

303.text: First of all, a word of caution: The cryptographic security of your files depends on the confidentiality of the associated encryption keys. Make sure that you transmit them via protected channels only! Standard e-mail, for example, is not good enough.

304.text: With that in mind, select one or multiple files in your file manager, then right-click and use "Get link". A dialog with the public link(s) to the file(s) you have selected will open. You can choose to export each link and key separately or as a single combo link.

306.text: All encryption is end-to-end. Data uploaded is encrypted on the uploading device before it is sent out to the Internet, and data downloaded is decrypted only after it has arrived on the downloading device.  The client machines are responsible for generating, exchanging and managing the encryption keys. No usable encryption keys ever leave the client computers (with the exception of RSA public keys).

307.text: Is all of my personal information subject to encryption?

308.text: No. Only file data and file/folder names are encrypted. Information that we need operational access to, such as your e-mail address, IP address, folder structure, file ownership and payment credentials, are stored and processed unencrypted. Please see our privacy policy for details.

309.text: Is my stored data absolutely secure?

310.text: All security is relative. The following attack vectors exist - they are not specific to MEGA, but we want you to know about the risks:

312.text: - Spyware on your computer. A simple keylogger is enough, but session credentials and keys could also be extracted from memory or the filesystem.

313.text: - Shoulder surfing. Do not type your password while someone could watch your keystrokes.

315.text: - Phishing. Always confirm the security status of your connection (https://) and the correct domain name (mega.nz) before entering your password.

316.text: Large-scale attacks could be mounted through:

317.text: - A "man in the middle" attack. Requires issuing a valid duplicate SSL certificate in combination with DNS forging and/or attacks on our BGP routes (a DigiNotar-style scenario).

318.text: - Gaining access to the webservers hosting https://mega.nz/index.html and replacing that file with a forged version (this would not affect access through the installed app base). Note that manipulating content on our distributed static content CDN does not pose a security risk, as all active content loaded from index.html is subject to verification with a cryptographic hash (think of it as some kind of "secure boot" for websites). This type of attack requires sending malicious code to the client and is therefore detectable.

319.text: - Gaining access to our core server infrastructure and creating forged key requests on existing shares. This type of attack only affects data in accounts with shared folders and is detectable on the client side as well.

320.text: What if I don't trust you? Is it still safe for me to use MEGA?

321.text: If you don't trust us, you cannot run any code provided by us, which precludes opening MEGA in your browser and entering your login credentials. However, due to MEGA's end-to-end encryption paradigm, you can safely use client applications written by someone you trust.

322.text: I trust you and your New Zealand data centre, but I don't trust your German data centre, because it is run by a US company.  Is it still safe for me to use MEGA?

323.text: Yes, you can still use MEGA (with a few limitations) safely with our core datacentre in Germany being fully compromised. The New Zealand data centre makes sure that no rogue code can run when you visit https://mega.nz/.

324.text: Is data that I put in shared folders as secure my other data?

325.text: Shared folders, by nature, are only as secure as their least secure member. However, a compromise of our core server infrastructure poses an additional risk: Public keys could be manipulated, and key requests could be forged.

326.text: Let's assume that a MEGA storage node is physically compromised. What are the risks?

327.text: Error messages after downloading manipulated files. Even if the attacker had the encryption key for a given file on that node, he could still not replace it with a forged one without causing the subsequent downloads to fail.

328.text: Is it a good idea to store all of my data in a single place?

329.text: Always keep redundant copies of important files, online and offline. Although we keep each file in at least two locations, there is no guarantee against multiple concurrent failures and repeated unprecedented government misconduct.

330.text: Why should I entrust my data to, of all people, you?

331.text: We provide for user controlled encryption (UCE) where you, the user, control the keys. The UCE implementation is open source, and we invite and encourage the community to scrutinize it and provide feedback. We believe that this approach is much safer than storing your data on a provider with server-side encryption where the ISP controls the keys or, worse, no encryption at all. For example, if MEGA user files were suddenly accessible without a password due to a programming error, they would be unreadable without the user-controlled decryption keys.

332.text: I noticed that you are using HTTPS for transferring already encrypted file data. Isn't that redundant?

333.text: It is. Unfortunately, most browsers take offence with establishing insecure connections from a secure page, and who could blame them for that - they can't possibly be aware of the fact that there is another encryption layer already in operation. Because HTTPS has an adverse effect on performance, we allow you to turn it off on browsers that allow it (Safari and Firefox until version 17) to speed up your transfers without jeopardizing the confidentiality or integrity of your data. You will see an SSL warning appear upon your first file transfer in some browsers - in this (and only in this) case, it is safe to ignore.

334.text: What encryption algorithms does MEGA use internally?

335.text: For bulk transfers, AES-128 (we believe that the higher CPU utilization of AES-192 and AES-256 outweighs the theoretical security benefit, at least until the advent of quantum computers). Post-download integrity checking is done through a chunked variation of CCM, which is less efficient than OCB, but not encumbered by patents.

336.text: For establishing shared secrets between users and dropping files into your inbox, RSA-2048 (the key length was chosen as middle grounds between "too insecure" and "too slow"). All encryption, decryption and key generation is implemented in JavaScript, which limits throughput to a few MB/s and causes significant CPU load. We are looking forward to the implementation of the proposed HTML5 WebCrypto API in all major browsers, which will eliminate this bottleneck.

337.text: JavaScript's built-in random number generator is enhanced through a mouse/keyboard timing-driven RC4 entropy pool as well as crypto.* randomness where available (Chrome and Firefox only at the moment - keys generated by Internet Explorer and Safari are less secure than they could be).
337.context: We collect random data from the user's mouse movements to ensure the key is completely random (rather than depending on the standard Javascript random function which are more predictable). Please read this for more info: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)

338.text: Does MEGA keep backups of my files?

339.text: We store your files on at least two servers in different datacentres, if available.

340.text: I have forgotten my password. Can I reset it?

344.text: When do I need to upgrade to a Pro account?

345.text: A Pro account gives you additional storage space and extra bandwidth quota that we automatically draw from whenever an operational bandwidth limit is reached - you can use the quota yourself, or grant it to third parties accessing your data (this includes users without a MEGA account).  The maximum percentage of your bandwidth quota allocated to third parties is configurable in your account settings.

346.text: What is the upload speed limiting feature good for?

347.text: Many routers do not prioritize smaller packets in case of link congestion, resulting in your inbound traffic being severely affected when your outbound link is full. We therefore offer an automatic speed management option where we measure your available outbound bandwidth during the initial ten seconds of an upload and then keep at least 10% of it unused. You can also set a fixed throughput limit.

348.text: What do I get with my free account?

349.text: A globally accessible, high-performance, secure cloud drive with [X] of storage space. If you need more than that, you can upgrade to a [A1]Pro[/A1] account. Click [A2]here[/A2] to see your current utilization.
349.context: IMPORTANT: Please apply the [X], [A1], [/A1], [A2] & [/A2] variables correctly to your translation.

361.text: Yes. Please use our software development kit to add MEGA support to your application.

362.text: To prevent resource overload, we sometimes have to cap bandwidth utilization. The file you are trying to download is larger than our current limit of [X3]. Its transfer has been postponed and will start automatically once the congestion eases.

365.text: Your browser is not modern enough to download a file this large.

674.text: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence. Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference.

675.text: Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 12

676.text: MEGA is Cloud Storage with Powerful Always-On Privacy

677.text: MEGA provides robust cloud storage with convenient and powerful always-on privacy. MEGA believes in your right to privacy and provides you with the technology tools to protect it. We call it User Controlled Encryption, or UCE, and it happens automatically.

678.text: What is MEGA User Controlled Encryption?

679.text: All files stored on MEGA are encrypted. All data transfers from and to MEGA are encrypted. And while most cloud storage providers can and do claim the same, MEGA is different – unlike the industry norm where the cloud storage provider holds the decryption key, with MEGA, you control the encryption, you hold the keys, and you decide who you grant or deny access to your files, without requiring any risky software installs. It’s all happening in your web browser!

681.text: The MEGA cloud is just the beginning. In the future, MEGA will provide UCE in your browser for a wide range of applications without the need to install anything. Our technology will protect your emails, calls, chats and video streams.

693.text: We are a dedicated group of technologists who were given the time, opportunity and Internet access to build an awesome cloud storage service that will help protect your privacy. We have programmed this Internet service from scratch in Auckland, New Zealand. Unlike most of our competitors, we use a state of the art browser based encryption technology where you, not us, control the keys. Our design group includes Kim Dotcom, Mathias Ortmann, Bram van der Kolk, and Finn Batato. Tony Lentino, owner of domain registrar Instra Corporation, is our Principal Visionary. Our CEO, Vikram Kumar, has been Chief Executive of InternetNZ, a non-profit organization promoting the vision of an 'open and uncapturable Internet'. We hope you like it.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography

Public-key cryptography, also known as asymmetric cryptography, refers to a cryptographic algorithm which requires two separate keys one of which is secret (or private) and one of which is public. Although different, the two parts of this key pair are mathematically linked. The public key is used to encrypt plaintext or to verify a digital signature; whereas the private key is used to decrypt ciphertext or to create a digital signature.

1821.text: When we launched MEGA early 2013, global mass surveillance by rogue governments under the pretext of fighting terrorism was still a wild conjecture and its proponents were often touted as conspiracy theorists. Edward Snowden's revelations 137 days later fundamentally changed public attitudes and it became excruciatingly clear that security by policy ("we have access to your data, but we promise to keep it confidential and not misuse it") had not been good enough. Anything short of security by design ("we cannot gain access to your data without you being able to find out"), for which strong end-to-end encryption is an essential prerequisite, now seems grossly insufficient.
1821.context: Text for the about us page

1822.text: MEGA was architected around the simple fact that cryptography, for it to be accepted and used, must not interfere with usability. MEGA is fully accessible without prior software installs and remains the only cloud storage provider with browser-based high-performance end-to-end encryption. The only visible signs of the crypto layer operating under MEGA's hood are the entropy collection during signup, the lack of a password reset feature and the novel (and browser-specific) ways file transfers are conducted. Today, millions of business and personal users rely on MEGA to securely and reliably store and serve petabytes of data and we believe that this success is the result of MEGA's low barrier to entry to a more secure cloud.

1823.text: We are constantly hiring. If you are an outstanding software engineer and would like to join our global team, please do not hesitate to submit your CV to jobs@mega.nz.

1824.text: You are currently logged in. Would you like to log out and register a new account?
1824.context: Confirmation message, that we show when the user clicks an invite link to register a new account while the user is logged in.

1826.text: MEGAsync is an installable application that synchronizes folders between your computer and your MEGA cloud drive. All files and subfolders will be replicated both ways. Changes that you make on one side will appear on the other side in near real time (within the limits of link/system latency and file transfer times).

1828.text: Go to the [A]download page[/A] and follow the instructions. During the installation, you will be asked to enter or create your MEGA account and to set up the folders to replicate (either your full MEGA cloud drive and folder structure to a single local folder location or specific subfolders in your cloud drive to corresponding local folders). After the installation completes, MEGAsync will start automatically. You will see a clickable MEGA logo in your system tray or menu bar while the sync tool is running that gives you access to a status popup and the settings page.

1829.text: Can I use MEGAsync on multiple computers?

1830.text: Yes. By synchronizing multiple devices with the same cloud folder, you can achieve cross-computer syncing (provided you use the same MEGA account on each device).

1831.text: How can I monitor the sync status of my local files and folders?

1832.text: Icons of files and folders that are in sync with the cloud will be tagged with a green circle. Transfers in progress are indicated by a blue circle; pending transfers show in red.

1833.text: MEGAsync stores my login credentials to perform autologin. Isn't that a security concern?

1834.text: Not if you keep your local drive encrypted (please do - why would you want to sync from an encrypted cloud drive to an unencrypted local drive?).

1835.text: I deleted a file from a local synced folder while MEGAsync was not running. Then I started it, and the file reappeared. Why?

1836.text: The current version of MEGAsync does not remember your local filesystem state across restarts. It has no way of knowing that a local file has gone missing since the last time it was run. Therefore, always keep MEGAsync running if you want your local deletions to be replicated properly.

1837.text: An important file was overwritten or deleted by the sync client. What can I do to get it back?

1838.text: On the cloud side, deleted files will be moved to a special "SyncDebris" subfolder structure in your rubbish bin and can be retrieved from there (use MEGA's built-in search if needed). On the local computer, each sync's root folder will have a hidden "Debris" or ".rubbish" folder in which deleted items are placed.

1839.text: Does MEGAsync perform explicit file versioning?
1839.context: e.g. when a user updates a file (a partial write operation), the user would have the ability to go back in time and reverse the operation, which is currently not supported by MEGA

1840.text: No. However, you can access overwritten files in the respective debris folders until they are purged.

1841.text: Does MEGAsync support modifying existing files?

1842.text: No. If a synced file changes, it is always replaced as a whole. Therefore, it is not recommended to sync e.g. large log files or database tables. Encrypted delta writes are planned for a future release.

1845.text: Are there any restrictions with regards to filenames?

1846.text: MacOS/UNIX filenames are case sensitive, Windows filenames are not. A folder containing both "ABC.TXT" and "abc.txt" can be synced to a UNIX machine without problems, but when synced to a Windows machine, only one of the two files will survive.

1847.text: MEGA imposes no restrictions on filenames - they can contain characters that are incompatible with the operating system, such as : or *. These will be rewritten as %xx on the local side and converted back to the original character when synced back. The Windows Explorer also has trouble with a number of seemingly innocuous file and folder names - "con.doc", for example, would not be accessible (to understand why, you have to be a geek or a veteran, or both). If you encounter such a situation, simply rename the file on the cloud side. Foreign characters in filenames are fully supported.

1848.text: MEGAsync supports fairly deep folder structures (MEGA itself is limited to a maximum of 63 levels) and very long pathnames (up to 32,000 characters under Windows). Unfortunately, most Windows software (including the Explorer) is unable to access files whose path is longer than 260 characters.

1849.text: How can I make sure that I always have the latest version of MEGAsync?

1850.text: MEGAsync checks for a new version every two hours and updates itself once one is available (you can turn this off in the settings - the next check is then performed when you turn it back on). For security reasons, only the account that initially installed MEGAsync is allowed to update it.

1851.text: Will MEGAsync use peer-to-peer transfers to achieve faster syncing between computers in the same local area network?

1852.text: No. The current incarnation of MEGAsync always syncs via MEGA's cloud infrastructure.

1853.text: What happens if conflicting concurrent actions are performed on clients synced to the same cloud location?

1854.text: The current version of MEGAsync does not resolve such clashes in a deterministic manner. Avoid them if possible.

1855.text: Does MEGAsync support advanced filesystem features such as links, attributes, ACLs, streams/forks or sparse files?

1856.text: No. Do not expect these to be replicated to the cloud.

1857.text: Does MEGAsync support syncing the same local folder to different remote locations or the same remote folder to different local locations?

1858.text: No, unless you want to run multiple MEGAsync processes in parallel, which is not recommended. As a general rule, each filesystem item must only be visible to MEGAsync once, so avoid syncing subfolders of synced folders or placing multiple links to the same filesystem item in a local synced folder.
1858.context: Whether you can sync one local folder to multiple remote folders, which is not possible. Each local folder can only be synced to one remote folder

1984.text: Your data is only readable through a chain of decryption operations that begins with your master encryption key, which we store encrypted with your password. This means that if you lose your password, your master key can no longer be decrypted, and you can no longer decrypt your data.

1985.text: Exporting the master key and keeping it in a secure location enables you to set a new password without data loss.

1986.text: An external attacker cannot gain access to your account with just your key. A password reset requires both the key and access to your e-mail.

1994.text: Yes. However, your MEGA password is more than just a password - it unlocks your master encryption key, without which your data is entirely unreadable. Therefore, there are two kinds of password reset: With or without providing a copy of your backed up master key. With the key, you can just set a new password and retain your existing account. Without the key, you can park your existing account and start a new one under your existing account's e-mail address. We recommend that you do keep a backup of your master key in a safe location at all times, just in case! Click here to export your key or here to reset your password.
1994.context: Updated answer to the question "I have forgotten my password. Can I reset it?" Please make sure you put the HTML tags for the links appropriately into the translation ("e.g.: here")

1995.text: I just remembered the password of my old account after performing a password reset. How do I get my data back?

1996.text: If less than 60 days have passed since you parked your old account, your data can be recovered. Please contact [A]support@mega.nz[/A] for assistance.
1996.context: Help section answer. Please put the [A] & [/A] tag appropriately in the translation.

1997.text: MEGA is asking me to make a backup of my master encryption key. Why?

1998.text: If you are positively sure that you will never lose your password, there is no need to back up your master key. If you do decide to make a [A]backup[/A], however, please ensure that you keep it in a safe location: Anyone with access to your backed up key and your e-mail account will be able to reset your password and gain access to your data.
1998.context: Help section answer. Please make sure you put the [A] & [/A] tags appropriately in the translation.

1999.text: Can I sync FAT/FAT32 partitions under Windows?

2000.text: While it may appear to work at first glance, we strongly advise against it, because FAT timestamps are timezone dependent, resulting in all of your files being re-synced twice a year if you live in an area observing daylight saving time. Unfortunately, the following fundamental design flaw in the Windows API design makes it difficult to dynamically compensate for such changes: "When it becomes daylight saving time, the time retrieved by GetFileTime is off an hour, because the cache is not updated. When you restart the computer, the cached time that GetFileTime retrieves is correct." In other words, do yourself a favour and avoid FAT.

5526.text:
MEGA is a secure cloud storage service that gives you 50GB for free.Unlike other cloud storage providers, your data is encrypted and decrypted by the client devices only and never by us.
Your data is accessible any time, from any device, anywhere. Share folders with your contacts and see their updates in real time.
The cloud in your pocket. Access and stream your files from your smartphone or tablet. Upload and sync your media to the cloud.
Search, store, download, stream, view, share, rename or delete your files. It's all there - in the palm of your hands.
For more info, please check our website: https://mega.nz/

5834.text:
MEGA is a secure cloud storage service with 50 GB free storage space.

Inside the app you can upgrade your storage space & bandwidth quota by subscribing to MEGA Pro with a monthly or yearly subscription.
Subscriptions are €9.99 (US$10.99) per month or €99.99 (US$119.99) per year.
This subscription gives you 500 GB of storage space and 1000 GB of bandwidth per month.
Subscriptions are renewed automatically for successive subscription periods of the same duration and at the same price as the initial period chosen. You can switch off the automatic renewal of your MEGA Pro subscription no later than 24 hours before your next subscription payment is due via your iTunes account settings page. To manage your subscriptions, simply click on the App Store icon on your handset, sign in with your Apple ID at the bottom of the page (if you haven't already done so) and then click View
ID. You'll be taken to your account page where you can scroll down to Manage App Subscriptions. From here, you can select your
MEGA Pro subscription and view your scheduled renewal date, choose a different subscription package or toggle the on-off switch to
off to disable the auto-renewal of your subscription.

Terms of Service:
https://mega.nz/ios_terms.html
Privacy policy:
https://mega.nz/ios_privacy.html

5835.text:
With PhotoSync, the photos you take with your iPhone will be automatically backed up to MEGA.
You can use WiFi or cellular connection and by enabling Background mode the app will upload photos when your location changes significantly.

Passcode lock adds a new layer of security by requiring a four-digit passcode to be entered every time the app is launched. This will protect your files even if your iPhone falls into the wrong hands. There is also an option to erase all data and logout if the wrong password is entered over 10 times.

Various bug fixes and speed improvements.

Your feedback is very important to us and, although we might not answer every email, we read each and every one.

Also, your 5-stars rating in the AppStore is always appreciated.

5909.text:
MacOS/UNIX filenames are case sensitive, Windows filenames are not. A folder containing both "ABC.TXT" and "abc.txt" can be synced to a UNIX machine without problems, but when synced to a Windows machine, only one of the two files will survive.

MEGA imposes no restrictions on filenames - they can contain characters that are incompatible with the operating system, such as : or *. These will be rewritten as %xx on the local side and converted back to the original character when synced back. The Windows Explorer also has trouble with a number of seemingly innocuous file and folder names - "con.doc", for example, would not be accessible (to understand why, you have to be a geek or a veteran, or both). If you encounter such a situation, simply rename the file on the cloud side. Foreign characters in filenames are fully supported.

MEGAsync supports fairly deep folder structures (MEGA itself is limited to a maximum of 63 levels) and very long pathnames (up to 32,000 characters under Windows). Unfortunately, most Windows software (including the Explorer) is unable to access files whose path is longer than 260 characters.

6295.text: Copyright -  is a legal concept, enacted by most governments, giving the creator of an original work exclusive rights to it, usually for a limited time. Generally, it is "the right to copy", but also gives the copyright holder the right to be credited for the work, to determine who may adapt the work to other forms, who may perform the work, who may financially benefit from it, and other related rights. It is a form of intellectual property (like the patent, the trademark, and the trade secret) applicable to any expressible form of an idea or information that is substantive and discrete.

6296.text: MEGA respects the copyrights of others and requires that users of the MEGA cloud service comply with the laws of copyright. You are strictly prohibited from using the MEGA cloud service to infringe copyrights. You may not upload, download, store, share, display, stream, distribute, e-mail, link to, transmit or otherwise make available any files, data, or content that infringes any copyright or other proprietary rights of any person or entity.

6298.text: Be aware that accounts that get targeted by multiple 'Take Down's' due to suspected copyright infringements may be suspended.

6300.text: You can share any subtree of your cloud drive with friends, family or coworkers. Invitation is by e-mail address. Invitees who do not have an account yet will receive an e-mail notification with a signup link. Alternatively, you can create a public link to any of your folders and export the folder-specific crypto key, making it accessible without a MEGA account. It is then your responsibility to securely transmit the folder key to the recipient(s).

6302.text: Select a folder you want to share with your colleague - right click that folder and select 'Sharing'. Enter your friends email address and permission level in the pop up window that appears.  There are three access levels: Read-only, read/write (files can be added, but not deleted), and full (files can be added and deleted).

6303.text: If your colleague does not have a MEGA account, they will receive an invite email in their email inbox to create their own free account.

6304.text: If they already have an account with MEGA, your email address will appear under their 'Contacts' in their Mega account and the shared folder can be found in the 'Incoming shares' section. They will also receive a Notification inside their account.

6306.text: Please double check the each user has each other's email ID added to 'Contacts'. If a 'share' from a new contact hasn't automatically added the email ID this share came from into 'Contacts' please make sure you add that email ID manually (Contact - Add Contact).

6307.text: If you added an e-mail address that did not have an account yet, you need to be online at least once after the recipient completes the signup process so that you can encrypt the share secret to his newly created public key.

6308.text: Right-clicking on any folder in your Cloud Drive and selecting 'Reload' also helps with recent updates.

6309.text: Simply right click on a folder in your Cloud Drive and select Sharing. You will see all people that currently have access (and access level) to the shared folder.

6310.text: Right click on the person and click the remove symbol 'x' option from the menu.

6311.text: To leave an incoming share go to 'Incoming shares', right-click on the folder and select 'Leave share' from the menu.

6312.text: Shared folders (outgoing) in your Cloud Drive have a special icon with three silhouettes on the folder.

6313.text: Your incoming shares are visible in 'Incoming shares' section.

6314.text: No. Folder shares are non-transitive to prevent any unauthorised re-distribution.

6315.text: First of all, a word of caution: The cryptographic security of your files depends on the confidentiality of the associated encryption keys. Make sure that you transmit them via protected channels only! Standard e-mail, for example, is not good enough.

6317.text: Select a file you want to share with your friend - right click and select 'Get link'.  A pop up window will appear. Copy and paste this 'File Link' and 'File Key' into a new email (for increased security separate file link and file key into two messages. Sending both the Link and the key together is not very secure. You can email it to your friend via secure channels.

6318.text: When the recipient receives your email and clicks on your link, a Mega window will appear and give them options:

6322.text: Right-click on the folder that already has a link generated and select 'Sharing'. In the 'Sharing' interface you will see an existing 'Link' with a switch set on 'ON'. Simply click on the 'ON' switch and drag it across the field to 'OFF'.

6323.text: To change a link to the same data:

6324.text: Folder - deactivate the link (if you wish) as described above. Then - you can change the existing 'Folder Link' by creating a new folder in your MEGA account under a new folder name. Then move or copy the file/s into this new folder. Then right-click on the new folder, select to 'Get Link' again and MEGA will generate a new 'Folder Link & Key'.

6325.text: File - you can either 'copy' the file into a new destination in your Cloud Drive and then, when in the new folder / Cloud Drive, right-click and select 'Get link'

6326.text: Alternatively you can remove the file and re-upload the data again. Then you can generate a brand new link to this data.

6327.text: Our users can generate a 'File Link' as well as the decryption key ('File key'). The reason users split the link from the key, is to make the file more difficult to access for unauthorized users, as you need both the link and the key to successfully complete the download.

6328.text: To generate both file link and file (decryption) key -  right-click on the desired file, select 'Get Link' (including the File Key) and copy to clipboard. Then you can paste into your URL or a message to a friend.

6329.text: Take this link for example:  (This is just a sample picture from my account, you can try these links to understand how it works)

6330.text: https://mega.nz/#!qIB1UICR!Wwhs4wI9ifAMDLISZgHwNV9fyA1JWbauAPepZUQoB00 - If you click on the link above, you can share it with others straight away, or you could send it the link split up (which would add more security, as the end user would need both the link and the key to get the file to download.)

6331.text: https://mega.nz/#!qIB1UICR - This portion is the 'File Link'

6332.text: Wwhs4wI9ifAMDLISZgHwNV9fyA1JWbauAPepZUQoB00 - This portion is the 'File Key' (You can see that this is just the second half of the complete link)

6333.text: If you click on the short link, it will ask you for the file (decryption) key, which is where you just paste the second half of the link into, thus unlocking the file, and making it retrievable.

6334.text: If you don't have the decryption key to a file that was shared with you - you will need to get the key from the generator of the link. The user who uploaded and shared the data.

6335.text: The streaming feature of audio and video file types is already possible on the MEGA iOS app and in our Android app. We are currently working on implementation for BlackBerry app, Windows Phone app as well as in-browser.

6336.text: The preview feature of image file types is now possible in both most compatible browsers Mozilla Firefox (+ MEGA extension https://mega.nz/#firefox) and Google Chrome (+ MEGA extension https://mega.nz/#chrome).

6337.text: Because encrypted in-browser video streaming and document preview deployment is going to be very difficult, so it will be more of a later-stage feature.

6338.text: What you can do is to connect the two accounts through a share. You can only share folders, so you need to put all files and folders under one master folder in your file manager (In the account with the data in it). Lets call this Account 1.

6339.text: Then right-click on the master folder, which has all your other folders and files in it, and select 'sharing' and add Account 2 email address and grant full access. You can then log into Account 2 and you will see the folder available to you in 'Incoming Shares' area.

6340.text: You can have both Account 1 and Account 2 open in different tabs to make things easier.

6341.text: That is the sharing method, you can also achieve the same outcome by generating a link for yourself to follow :

6343.text: You can right click on the files within the folder (or the whole folder) and select 'Get Link & Key', then open up a new tab, copy and paste these links into browser, and it will bring up an option to 'Import'. From there, you log into Account 2, refresh the page, and all the files form the master folder will now have been imported into your Account 2.

6344.text: The easiest way to transfer your files over is to install our Sync client (https://mega.nz/#sync) and sync all the data to your Cloud Drive through the client directly.

6443.text: All files stored on MEGA are encrypted. All data transfers from and to MEGA are encrypted. And while most cloud storage providers can and do claim the same, MEGA is different – unlike the industry norm where the cloud storage provider holds the decryption key, with MEGA, you control the encryption, you hold the keys, and you decide who you grant or deny access to your files, without requiring any risky software installs. It’s all happening in your web browser!

6444.text: All our encryption is end-to-end. Data uploaded is encrypted on the uploading device before it is sent out to the Internet, and data downloaded is decrypted only after it has arrived on the downloading device. The client machines are responsible for generating, exchanging and managing the encryption keys. No usable encryption keys ever leave the client computers (with the exception of RSA public keys).

6445.text: The nominated and confirmed password for your MEGA account is also your unique master encryption key to your files. You could have noticed this being created upon your 'confirmation email' validation. The encryption key gets created from your password and to strengthen the key we have collected the entropy from your mouse movements and key stroke timings.

6446.text: Remember to keep your MEGA password secure and confidential at all times and generate your MASTER CRYPTO KEY for the event of misplacing your password in the future - https://mega.nz/#backup.

6447.text: No. Only file data and file/folder names are encrypted. Information that we need operational access to, such as your e-mail address, IP address, folder structure, file ownership and payment credentials, are stored and processed unencrypted. Please see our privacy policy for details.

6449.text: We make no use of the data a user stores with us because we cannot even decrypt it. MEGA uses a unique system of User Controlled Encryption. BEFORE your data leaves your browser, the file is encrypted (scrambled, unreadable) and then it leaves your computer, to be stored on the cloud as unreadable. The only way to decrypt/ make it readable is to download it back, while logged in to your file manager. Only when it reaches your browser, and realizes you are logged in with the correct credentials, does it begin decrypting (become readable). The only way to get the file is to be correctly logged into that account. This is UCE.

6450.text: Server controlled encryption (other storage providers) means the file is still readable when it is sent to the cloud, and then it is encrypted. When downloading, it is decrypted at the cloud, and then sent back to you fully readable. Not hard for prying eyes to see what is going on!

6459.text: All security is relative. The following attack vectors exist - they are not specific to MEGA, but we want you to know about the risks:

6461.text: - Spyware on your computer. A simple keylogger is enough, but session credentials and keys could also be extracted from memory or the filesystem.

6462.text: - Shoulder surfing. Do not type your password while someone could watch your keystrokes.

6464.text: - Phishing. Always confirm the security status of your connection (https://) and the correct domain name (mega.nz) before entering your password.

6465.text: Large-scale attacks could be mounted through:

6466.text: - A "man in the middle" attack. Requires issuing a valid duplicate SSL certificate in combination with DNS forging and/or attacks on our BGP routes (a DigiNotar-style scenario).

6467.text: - Gaining access to the webservers hosting https://mega.nz/index.html and replacing that file with a forged version (this would not affect access through the installed app base). Note that manipulating content on our distributed static content CDN does not pose a security risk, as all active content loaded from index.html is subject to verification with a cryptographic hash (think of it as some kind of "secure boot" for websites). This type of attack requires sending malicious code to the client and is therefore detectable.

6468.text: For bulk transfers, AES-128 (we believe that the higher CPU utilization of AES-192 and AES-256 outweighs the theoretical security benefit, at least until the advent of quantum computers). Post-download integrity checking is done through a chunked variation of CCM, which is less efficient than OCB, but not encumbered by patents.

6469.text: For establishing shared secrets between users and dropping files into your inbox, RSA-2048 (the key length was chosen as middle grounds between "too insecure" and "too slow"). All encryption, decryption and key generation is implemented in JavaScript, which limits throughput to a few MB/s and causes significant CPU load. We are looking forward to the implementation of the proposed HTML5 WebCrypto API in all major browsers, which will eliminate this bottleneck.

6470.text: There is no need to worry. Anything we do send through RC4 is already encrypted from the point it leaves your browser so there is no security risk. For increased security make sure you have our browser extensions installed. MEGA's users get to enjoy the privacy of their data with our User Controlled Encryption (UCE) mechanism - the only storage provider on the market offering this level of security and privacy.

6471.text: We support AES on all of our SSL servers. "Perfect Forward Secrecy" is supported where needed. It is not needed where it is not supported.

6472.text: For our customers' sake, some things are really important to us. One of these things is obviously security, whereas another one is performance. However, the former cannot be trumped by the latter!!!

6473.text: When you log in, receive the `secureboot.js` file, or when you're connecting to our API, you will *always* be running through a properly configured web server, which will give you strong authentication, strong encryption, as well as forward secrecy (PFS). These are the places where it matters that information is transferred in a secure fashion when using SSL/TLS!

6474.text: Afterwards, when you're accessing further static content, or when you're accessing your file storage, the client side (that is for example the JavaScript code in your browser, a browser extension, a

6475.text: sync client or a mobile app) will take care of ensuring security. Every content further loaded off of servers (e. g. the *.static.mega.nz servers) will be verified cryptographically by the client, and the content that could be seen on the wire is harmless. Every time data is transferred to or from our storage servers, the client side code will take care of proper, strong encryption, so that only ever the client alone is able to get access to the actual plain data.

6476.text: Given these circumstances, we could actually serve all static content and/or data transfers with our storage servers over a completely unencrypted connection. There would be *no* lack in security!

6477.text: However, browsers will refuse to allow for unencrypted HTTP connections (for good reasons) when originating from an HTTPS encrypted site, or they will at least display a degradation in security in the browser bar. This is all very good and common practice, especially if SSL/TLS is your line of defence when transmitting plain text data. For those reasons also, all subsequent connections generally should be of similar good strength in protection. However, as stated above, we don't actually need an encrypted HTTPS connection to uphold our protection (as we've taken care to completely encrypt the actual content already). But, we can't remove SSL/TLS (HTTPS) completely, as that would make the look in the browser "unhappy". Therefore, we have opted to use the weakest

6478.text: possible protection (RC4 with MD5) as a "NULL cipher" to prevent the browser from alarming people, whereas we would even be happy with an unencrypted connection altogether. This will give the end user an enhanced performance, *without* decreasing any security. And this is actually what our other clients are doing, they're getting rid of even RC4/MD5, but use strong SSL/TLS where needed.

6479.text: I hope this rather lengthy description has cleared up the situation, and lets you enjoy MEGA without a stale feeling of insecurity or security by hand waving. We really do take it seriously, and have put *lots* of thoughts into it.

6555.text: This means however it will also synchronise mistakes made in your local folder, for example, if you accidentally overwrite a file in your local folder, that file will be updated in your MEGA account, hence it shouldn't be relied upon to backup live data.

6556.text: The best way of using MEGAsync for backups would be to create a local "Backups" folder on your computer and use a proper backup program (or even a batch file or script) to create a backup and save the backup file in this folder, which will then be synchronised to your MEGA account.

6557.text: Using this method will also allow you to create multiple backup files.

6558.text: For example using the date of the backup file, eg 22-10-14.zip, 23-10-14.zip, 24-10-14.zip, etc.

6559.text: These files will all be synchronised to your MEGA account and when you remove the oldest backup file from your computer to conserve space, it will also be removed from your MEGA account.

6566.text: However always keep redundant copies of important files, online and offline. Although we keep each file in at least two locations, there is no guarantee against multiple concurrent failures and repeated

6568.text: We provide for user controlled encryption (UCE) where you, the user, control the keys. The UCE implementation is open source, and we invite and encourage the community to scrutinise it and provide feedback.

6569.text: We believe that this approach is much safer than storing your data on a provider with server-side encryption where the ISP controls the keys or, worse, no encryption at all - if, for example, MEGA user files were suddenly accessible without a password due to a programming error, they would be unreadable without the user-controlled decryption keys.

6643.text: When you 'Create Account' with Mega (https://mega.nz/#register), the pop up on the page will tell you to expect a 'Confirmation Email' and you should go to your email inbox and look for a 'MEGA Activation' email.  In this 'Confirmation' email, you click on the confirmation link which takes you to Mega again to put in your password for the second time so that you can authenticate your account.  If successful, you are taken to your Mega account displaying 'Cloud Drive'.

6645.text: If you haven’t received the email to confirm/activate your account, please check your junk mail folder and spam filters at your email address.

6646.text: If you still can’t locate the email, you might try to re-register using the original email address.  If the confirmation email for this registration does not appear in any of your email folders, then we suggest that you contact your ISP to determine if there is a 'block' on Mega emails.  Alternatively you may need to sign up using a different email ID.

6647.text: If you are getting the warning message "Incorrect password / email ID" - that appears when the password you entered at the point of registration and the password you try to enter to validate and confirm your account don't match.

6648.text: We suggest to start registration again with the same email address and write the password down somewhere secure to validate it later. Try to make your password longer so it is not easily guessed. Combine upper and lower case letters, add special characters (we don't limit any!). Do not use names or dictionary words. Also do not use copy & paste function while creating your account - please make sure you type your password in each time when registering.

6649.text: We also strongly discourage users to use password generators as your password is also going to be your unique encryption key.

6651.text: If the activation link you have received after signing up at Mega does not work when you click on it try to copy and paste the link directly into your browser; check for any extra white space that your email client might have entered.

6652.text: If you still cannot activate your account try to re-register for a MEGA account with the same email address or sign up using a different email address to receive a new confirmation link.

6653.text: Ensure you regularly clear your browser cache and that you are not logged into another MEGA account from the same browser while registering for a new one.

6682.text: The privacy and security you get with browser based end to end encryption can take it's toll on speed as due to not all browsers provide complete HTML5 support. MEGA's users get to enjoy the privacy of their data with our User Controlled Encryption (UCE) mechanism - the only storage provider on the market offering this level of security and privacy.

6683.text: The speed of downloads/uploads is dependent on the state and speed of your computer, software, operating systems and versions and your ISP provider. With Mega, you can control the 'speed' of downloads or uploads, depending on your priorities in 'My Account' - 'Transfer Settings'. You can try to maximize your upload performance by disabling the 'Upload Speed Limit' as well.

6684.text: We do default the 'Upload Speed Limit' to enabled as many routers do not prioritize smaller packets in case of link congestion, resulting in your inbound traffic being severely affected when your outbound link is full. We therefore measure your available outbound bandwidth during the initial ten seconds of an upload and then keep at least 10% of it unused.

6685.text: The speed tests such as speedtest.net are great when you want to determine if your router or ISP has issues – you know what your speed ‘should’ be and this test indicates if there is an issue somewhere along the ‘lines’. However the result from speed test does not have a direct relation to speed with MEGA. The speed test will indicate whether everything is working right from the users or ISP’s end however there are other factors to take into consideration. Such as international peering issues (internet as a whole is currently experiencing: http://www.internetpulse.com/); the state of users computer (whether your software is up to date, whether your HDD and browser are clogged by temp or cached data or fragmented…); transfer speed also depends which server we are storing the data on.

6686.text: To sum it up - your Pro account's increased bandwidth does not have any relation to 'speed' however greater bandwidth may improve the speed of your traffic indirectly.

6714.text: In order for any of the following to make sense, I urge you to get into MEGA, and start testing for yourself, and see how what i am about to describe can apply!

6715.text: OK, the way to do this :

6716.text: Firstly, the leader of this project, or the file administrator would set up an account which would be considered the MASTER account - This can just be a normal Free account, or Pro (https://mega.nz/#pro) depending on your storage requirements.

6717.text: 1 - Each other user must have an account set up with MEGA.nz - They are Free :)

6718.text: 2 - You need to add each of their email IDs to your master account's Contacts.

6719.text: 3 - In your master account, it is up to you to set up the 'hierarchy' as described. E.g. you would create a different folder unique to each user, you could call it by their name.

6720.text: 4 - Once you have set up the 'hierarchy' to reach the level that you need uploaded to (e.g. User/ Event and sub folder, Users name)

6721.text: you can then 'right click' select sharing, and assign that user with FULL ACCESS!

6722.text: 5 - From here, this folder is effectively synced on both accounts, any modifications are visible at both accounts instantly!

6723.text: You then load files into that folder, and they will be visible at the other users account too, listed under their 'Incoming Shares'

6724.text: Then are also notifications to alert all users with access to that folder, of any recent activities such as new files added, removed etc.

6725.text: FULL Access allows both the master account, and the receiving account with full permissions to that folder. Each user could upload, download, modify and erase any content in that folder. The other permission levels are Read Only (no adding, no deleting) and Read and Write (you can add but not delete).
